newsitem.title: DENMARK: ISS may withdraw from U.S. stock market.
newsitem.headline: ISS may withdraw from U.S. stock market.

text.p: Danish cleaning group International Service System (ISS), which sold its troubled U.S. unit last May, said on Tuesday that it may remove its thinly-traded share from the New York market as a consequence.
"It's an issue that we are addressing with the board and we'll make a decision by the end of the year," Managing Director Waldemar Schmidt said in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.
"We only have 0.3 percent of our share capital in the ADR programme and the trading volume is extremely low; we're talking about a few hundred shareholders," he added.
He said that the majority of U.S. and Canadian investors bought the Copenhagen-listed B-share.
"So the likelihood is that we at the end of the year will come to the conclusion that we might de-list (in New York)."
ISS was hit heavily in 1996 by losses incurred over falsified accounting in U.S. unit ISS Inc, which it sold last March to Canada's Aaxis Ltd.
On Tuesday the group showed itself bouncing back, with first half 1997 net profit of 83 million crowns compared to a loss of 2.02 billion in the first six months of 1996.
